questions.text: Which of the following statements about heme synthesis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: ALA synthase requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor.

options.label: B
options.text: ALA dehydratase contains zinc as a cofactor and is inhibited by lead.

options.label: C
options.text: Pyridoxal phosphate deficiency can lead to anemia due to impaired ALA synthase activity.

options.label: D
options.text: ALA dehydratase is the rate-limiting step of the heme synthesis pathway.

questions.correct_answer: D. ALA dehydratase is the rate-limiting step of the heme synthesis pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following organs can utilize ketone bodies for energy, and which enzyme is involved in their metabolism?
questions.explanation:
KETOSIS

Ketone Bodies
  • Produced in the liver
  • Utilized by extrahepatic tissues due to the absence of Thiophorase enzyme in the liver

Tissues that use Ketone Bodies
  • Almost all tissues except:
    • Liver
    • Red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Tissues that prefer ketone bodies:
    • Heart muscle
    • Renal cortex
    • Placenta
 
  • Tissues that use ketone bodies only in the absence of glucose:
    • Skeletal muscle
    • Brain
 
  • Additional Tissues Using Ketone Bodies
    • Intestinal mucosal cells
    • Adipocytes

Enzyme Involved
  • Thiophorase: Converts acetoacetate to acetoacetyl CoA

Fatty Acids as Primary Energy Source During Starvation
  • Skeletal muscles
  • Heart
  • Liver

Energy Production Pathway
  • Acetoacetyl CoA enters the beta-oxidation pathway to produce energy

questions.text: What is the Total and Net ATP used in the complete oxidation of Arachidonic acid?
Which one of the following does not occur during β-oxidation of fatty acids?

options.label: A
options.text: Dehydrogenation of fatty acyl-CoA to trans-enoyl-CoA

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of acetyl-CoA from β-keto fatty acyl-CoA

options.label: C
options.text: Conversion of trans-enoyl-CoA to saturated fatty acyl-CoA

options.label: D
options.text: Hydration of trans-enoyl-CoA to β-hydroxy fatty acyl-CoA

questions.correct_answer: C. Conversion of trans-enoyl-CoA to saturated fatty acyl-CoA
questions.explanation:
Step 1:FAD-Linked Dehydrogenation
  • Catalyzed by Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase
  • Fatty acyl-CoA → trans-enoyl-CoA (FADH₂ produced). (Option A ruled out)
  • FADH₂ generates 1.5 ATP in the electron transport chain.

Step 2:Hydration
  • Catalyzed by enoyl-CoA hydratase.
  • Converts trans-enoyl-CoA to β-hydroxy fatty acyl-CoA (only L isomer formed). (Option D ruled out)

Step 3:NAD⁺-Dependent Dehydrogenation
  • Catalyzed by β-hydroxy acyl-CoA dehydrogenase
  • β-Hydroxy fatty acyl-CoA → β-keto fatty acyl-CoA (NADH produced).
  • NADH generates 2.5 ATP in the electron transport chain

Cleavage
  • Catalyzed by Acyl CoA Acetyltransferase (Thiolase)
  • β-Keto fatty acyl-CoA undergoes thiolytic cleavage.
  • Produces one acetyl-CoA and a shorter fatty acyl-CoA for further cycles. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Lead poisoning can cause acquired porphyria by inhibiting several enzymes in the heme synthesis pathway. Which of the following enzymes is not affected by lead poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Enzyme inhibited

Features

ALA dehydratase (Option A)

ALA elevation

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option B)

Coproporphyrin elevation

Ferrochelatase (Option C)

Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels (Most sensitive marker)

questions.text: Match the following disorder with its clinical classification: Disorder Clinical Manifestations A.Acute intermittent porphyria i) Neuropsychiatric manifestations B.Porphyria Cutanea Tarda ii) Photosensitivity C.Hereditary coproporphyria iii) Both Neuropsychiatric manifestation and photosensitivity D.Congenital erythropoietic porphyria

A 25-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Blood tests reveal microcytic anemia with elevated serum iron and ferritin levels. Bone marrow biopsy shows ringed sideroblasts. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the ALAS2 gene. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

X-Linked Sideroblastic Anemia (XLSA)

Autosomal Recessive Sideroblastic Anemia (ARSA)

(Option D)

Genetic Cause

Mutation in the ALAS2 gene

Mutations in various genes involved in glycine transport into mitochondria, including SLC25A38 and GLRX5

Gender Predominance

Primarily affects males

It affects both males and females equally

Clinical Presentation

Microcytic, hypochromic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; increased serum iron and ferritin

Microcytic anemia; ringed sideroblasts; variable symptoms

Pathway Affected

Heme synthesis (5-aminolevulinate synthase 2)

Mitochondrial function, iron-sulfur cluster biogenesis

Common Symptoms

Fatigue, pallor, weakness

Fatigue, pallor, weakness; potential systemic symptoms

Diagnosis

Genetic testing for ALAS2 mutations

Genetic testing for specific gene mutations

Management Options

Pyridoxine, iron chelation, blood transfusions

Iron chelation, blood transfusions, supportive therapies

questions.text: Which of the following structures correctly represents the type of porphyrin? A= acetyl, P=propionyl, M=methyl, V=vinyl

options.label: A
options.text: A- Uroporphyrinogen I, B- Uroporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen I

options.label: B
options.text: D- Coproporphyrinogen III, C- Coproporphyrinogen I, E- Protoporphyrinogen I

options.label: C
options.text: A- Uroporphyrinogen III, B- Uroporphyrinogen I, E- Protoporphyrinogen III

options.label: D
options.text: D- Coproporphyrinogen I, C- Coproporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen III

questions.correct_answer: D. D- Coproporphyrinogen I, C- Coproporphyrinogen III, E- Protoporphyrinogen III
questions.explanation:
Uroporphyrinogen

 
  • Alternating acetyl (A) and propionyl (P) groups at all 8 positions.
  • Uroporphyrinogen I is when there is symmetry in all the rings.
  • Uroporphyrinogen III is when there is an asymmetry in the last ring.

Coproporphyrinogen

 
  • Instead of acetyl, methyl (M) groups are present.
  • The conversion from the acetyl to the methyl group is done by decarboxylation.
  • Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase converts uroporphyrinogen to coproporphyrinogen.

Protoporphyrinogen
  • In this case, a methyl (M)-vinyl (V) group is present only in rings 1 and 2.
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase converts coproporphyrinogen to protoporphyrinogen.
  • Protoporphyrinogen can be converted into protoporphyrin by oxidation (removal of hydrogen) by protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to severe photosensitivity and recurrent skin lesions that worsen upon sun exposure. The parents are paint factory workers living in an industrial complex. The child’s urine is noted to be dark red in color. Laboratory tests confirm elevated levels of porphyrins in the blood. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.

options.label: B
options.text: The red fluorescence of the teeth under UV light is referred to as erythrodontia, due to emission of 600 nm wavelength by porphyrin.

options.label: C
options.text: Porphyrin has a specific absorption band called Soret band corresponding to 400 nm.

options.label: D
options.text: Photosensitivity due to the accumulation of porphyrins in the skin which release superoxide radicals causing photooxidative damage.

questions.correct_answer: A. The condition can occur due to exposure to lead, leading to decreased activity of ALA synthase.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the protoporphyrin ring and its associated metals is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Heme is a derivative of porphyrin, a cyclic compound formed by the fusion of 4 pyrrole rings with a metallic group in the center

options.label: B
options.text: Heme-containing proteins such as myoglobin have Fe3+ as the metallic group.

options.label: C
options.text: Heme-containing enzymes are catalase, peroxidase, and nitric oxide synthase.

options.label: D
options.text: The metallic group in Chlorophyll is magnesium, while in cytochrome a/a3 is copper.

questions.correct_answer: B. Heme-containing proteins such as myoglobin have Fe3+ as the metallic group.
questions.explanation:
Porphyrin derived proteins

Metallic group in the center

Heme

  • Heme-containing proteins - Hemoglobin, Myoglobin, some cytochromes
  • Heme-containing enzymes- catalase, peroxidase, nitric oxide synthase (Option C)

Iron (Fe2+)

Hematin (Oxidized form of Heme)

Iron (Fe3+)

Cytochrome a/a3 (Option D)

Copper

Chlorophyll

Magnesium

questions.text: Which of the following fatty acids is needed for humans from diet as humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain?
questions.explanation:
Essential fatty acids

Non-essential fatty acids
  • Cannot be synthesized by the human body and must be obtained through the diet.
  • Humans cannot create double bonds beyond the 9th carbon atom from the carboxyl end of a fatty acid chain.
  • Linoleic Acid (LA): An omega-6 fatty acid.
  • Alpha-linolenic acid (ALA): An omega-3 fatty acid. (Option A)
  • Can be synthesized by the human body from other dietary fats
  • Palmitic acid (Option B ruled out)
  • Oleic acid (Option C ruled out)
  • Stearic acid (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Following are the substrates of cholesterol synthesis. Arrange them in order of appearance in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. Mevalonate Squalene Lanosterol Zymosterol Desmosterol
Which of the following pairs correctly associates a disease with its corresponding enzyme deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Fabry disease

α-Galactosidase

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

Krabbe disease

β-Galactocerebrosidase

Gaucher disease

β-Glucosidase

Niemann-Pick disease types A, B

Sphingomyelinase

Ceramidase

questions.text: A patient presents with bone pain, fatigue and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood tests reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy shows macrophages with a characteristic "wrinkled paper" appearance. Which substrate accumulates in Gaucher's disease due to the deficient enzyme activity?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Enzyme deficiency

Substance accumulation

Features

Tay-Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A, S

Ganglioside (Option C)
  • Mental retardation
  • Blindness
  • Muscular weakness
  • Cherry red spots in macula

Niemann-Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase

Sphingomyelin (Option A)
  • Enlarged liver and spleen
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

Farber disease

Ceramidase

Ceramide (Option D)
  • Hoarseness
  • Dermatitis
  • Skeletal deformation
  • Mental retardation
  • Fatal in early life

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of four consecutive miscarriages over the past three years. After a thorough evaluation, a diagnosis is made . Which of the following phospholipids is specifically antigenic in this disease?
questions.explanation:
Phospholipids

Location

  

Function

Synthesis

Significance

Phosphatidylserine

(Option A ruled out)

Inner leaflet of the plasma membrane
  • Involved in apoptosis.
  • It flips to the outer leaflet of the plasma membrane, serving as a signal for phagocytes to engulf the dying cell.

Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)

Plays a role in blood clotting by facilitating the binding of clotting factors.

Supports neuronal function.

Cardiolipin

(Option C)

inner mitochondrial membrane
  • optimal function of numerous enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Stabilizes the respiratory chain complexes and supercomplexes

Unique dimeric structure consisting of four fatty acid chains

Synthesized in the mitochondria from phosphatidylglycerol and cytidine diphosphate-diacylglycerol (CDP-DAG)

Antigenic

Phosphatidylinositol

(Option B ruled out)

plasma membrane and intracellular membranes
  • Involved in cell signaling pathways, particularly through the production of secondary messengers
  • Plays a role in membrane trafficking and cytoskeletal organization.

Produced in the ER and Golgi apparatus from CDP-DAG and inositol.

Crucial for the function of insulin signaling and other receptor-mediated signal transduction pathways.

Defects in phosphatidylinositol metabolism are linked to various diseases, including diabetes and cancer.

Phosphatidylethanolamine

(Option D ruled out)

All cellular membranes
  • Important for membrane fusion and the structural integrity of cellular membranes.
  • Serves as a precursor for the synthesis of phosphatidylserine.

Synthesized in the ER via the cytidine diphosphate-ethanolamine (CDP-ethanolamine) pathway or by decarboxylation of phosphatidylserine in the mitochondria.

Plays a role in lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics.

Deficiencies can impact cellular functions and are associated with various neurological disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Acetyl CoA metabolism?

options.label: A
options.text: It is produced in the cytoplasm from glucose via pyruvate oxidation.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be transported directly across the mitochondrial membrane to the cytoplasm.

options.label: C
options.text: It is converted to citrate in the mitochondria

options.label: D
options.text: It is involved in the production of NADPH in the cytoplasm.

questions.correct_answer: C. It is converted to citrate in the mitochondria

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Fatty acid synthase (FAS) complex is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The FAS complex synthesizes fatty acids exclusively in the mitochondria.

options.label: B
options.text: The primary product of the FAS complex is palmitic acid, a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid.

options.label: C
options.text: The FAS complex utilizes the same enzymes and intermediates as those found in β-oxidation.

options.label: D
options.text: Each subunit of the FAS complex consists of a single enzyme responsible for fatty acid synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: B. The primary product of the FAS complex is palmitic acid, a 16-carbon saturated fatty acid.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the products and by-products of the palmitic acid synthesis reaction?

options.label: D
options.text: 1 Palmitate + 7 CO₂ + 6 H₂O + 8 CoA−SH + 14 NADP⁺ + 14 H⁺

questions.correct_answer: B. 1 Palmitate + 7 CO₂ + 6 H₂O + 8 CoA−SH + 14 NADP+

questions.text: Which of the following inhibits Acetyl CoA Carboxylase?
questions.explanation:
Stimulated by High energy level states

Inhibited by Low energy level states.
  • NADH (Option B ruled out)
  • FADH2
  • ATP (Option C ruled out)
  • Citrate
  • Insulin: enhances the uptake of glucose by adipocytes and increases the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase, acetyl CoA carboxylase, and glycerol phosphate acyl transferase (Option D ruled out)
  • ADP
  • NAD
  • FAD
  • Glucagon(catabolic hormone) (Option A)
  • Acyl CoA
  • Epinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the type of lipid with its description?

options.label: A
options.text: Fats - Liquid at room temperature, often containing polyunsaturated fatty acids.

options.label: B
options.text: Phospholipids - Contain glycerol and are the main lipid constituents of cell membranes.

options.label: C
options.text: Glycolipids - Esters of fatty acids that never contain sphingosine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Phospholipids - Contain glycerol and are the main lipid constituents of cell membranes.
questions.explanation:
Classification of lipids

1.Simple Lipids

  • Esters of fatty acids with various alcohols.
  • Further classified into fats, oils & waxes

Fats

Esters of fatty acids with glycerol; solid at room temperature. (Option A ruled out)

Triacylglycerol with saturated fatty acids.

Oils

Fats in liquid state at room temperature.

Triacylglycerols with polyunsaturated fatty acids.

Waxes

Esters of fatty acids with higher molecular weight monohydric alcohols.

  

2.Complex Lipids

  • Esters of fatty acids with alcohol and other groups.
  • Further classified based on additional groups present as Phospholipids, glycolipids and other complex lipids

Phospholipids:

  • Contain phosphoric acid;
  • Main lipid constituents of membranes.

(Option B)

Glycerophospholipids

Alcohol is glycerol.


Phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine.

Sphingophospholipids

Alcohol is sphingosine

  

Sphingomyelin, found in myelin sheaths.

Glycolipids:

(glycosphingolipids)

  • Contain fatty acid, sphingosine, and carbohydrate;
  • Involved in cell adhesion and recognition

(Option C ruled out)

Cerebrosides

(Option D ruled out)

Galactosylceramide, a key component of myelin.

Globosides

Cell adhesion and Pathogen identification

Gangliosides

Highly concentrated in nerve tissues and function in cell-cell recognition, communication, and as receptors for hormones and bacterial toxins.

Other Complex Lipids

Includes sulfolipids, amino lipids, and lipoproteins.

  

3.Precursor/Derived Lipids

Formed from hydrolysis of simple and complex lipids; Also act as precursors for lipid formation.

Fatty acids, cholesterol, fatty aldehydes, ketone bodies, hydrocarbons, lipid-soluble vitamins, hormones.

questions.text: Match the lipoprotein with its function. Lipoprotein Function 1.Chylomicron a.Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue 2.Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) b.Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver 3. Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) c.Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues 4. High-density lipoprotein (HDL) d.Transports triglycerides from the gut to muscle and adipose tissue
questions.explanation:
Lipoprotein

Function

Chylomicron

Transports triglycerides from the gut to liver, muscle and adipose tissue

Very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL)

Transports triglycerides from the liver to muscle and adipose tissue

Intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL)

VLDL remnant

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)

Transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues

High-density lipoprotein (HDL)

Transports cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding bile acid synthesis regulation? 7α-hydroxylation is the step which is suppressed Cholic acid suppresses the synthesis Farnesoid X receptor is activated Transcription of the CYP7A1 gene is suppressed
